sn22.115:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.115:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn22.115:1.4.pli: kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dhammakathiko hotī”ti?
sn22.115:1.4.eng: How is a Dhamma speaker defined?”
sn22.115:1.4.comm: Applied to the senses at SN 35.155:1.2 and dependent origination at SN 12.16:1.3.

sn22.115:1.5.pli: “Rūpassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti ‘dhammakathiko bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.115:1.5.eng: “Mendicant, if a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.

sn22.115:1.6.pli: Rūpassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti, ‘dhammānudhammappaṭipanno bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.115:1.6.eng: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.

sn22.115:1.7.pli: Rūpassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādāvimutto hoti, ‘diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.115:1.7.eng: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.

sn22.115:1.8.eng: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment with feeling …

sn22.115:1.11.pli: viññāṇassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, ‘dhammakathiko bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.115:1.11.eng: consciousness, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.

sn22.115:1.12.pli: Viññāṇassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti, ‘dhammānudhammappaṭipanno bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.115:1.12.eng: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.

sn22.115:1.13.pli: Viññāṇassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādāvimutto hoti, ‘diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
sn22.115:1.13.eng: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”

sn22.116:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.116:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn22.116:1.4.pli: kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dhammakathiko hoti;
sn22.116:1.4.eng: How is a Dhamma speaker defined?

sn22.116:1.5.pli: kittāvatā dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hoti, kittāvatā diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto hotī”ti?
sn22.116:1.5.eng: How is a mendicant who practices in line with the teaching defined? And how is a mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life defined?”

sn22.116:1.6.pli: “Rūpassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, ‘dhammakathiko bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.116:1.6.eng: “Mendicant, if a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.

sn22.116:1.7.pli: Rūpassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti, ‘dhammānudhammappaṭipanno bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.116:1.7.eng: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.

sn22.116:1.8.pli: Rūpassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādāvimutto hoti, ‘diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.116:1.8.eng: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.

sn22.116:1.9.eng: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment with feeling …

sn22.116:1.12.pli: viññāṇassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, ‘dhammakathiko bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.116:1.12.eng: consciousness, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.

sn22.116:1.13.pli: Viññāṇassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti, ‘dhammānudhammappaṭipanno bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya.
sn22.116:1.13.eng: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.

sn22.116:1.14.pli: Viññāṇassa ce, bhikkhu, nibbidā virāgā nirodhā anupādāvimutto hoti, ‘diṭṭhadhammanibbānappatto bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
sn22.116:1.14.eng: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, they’re qualified to be called ‘a mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”

sn22.117:1.2.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī …pe… sappurisadhamme avinīto
sn22.117:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.117:1.3.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.117:1.3.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.117:1.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano rūpabandhanabaddho santarabāhirabandhanabaddho atīradassī apāradassī, baddho jīyati baddho mīyati baddho asmā lokā paraṃ lokaṃ gacchati.
sn22.117:1.4.eng: They’re called an unlearned ordinary person who is bound to form, inside and out. They see neither the near shore nor the far shore. They’re born in bonds and die in bonds, and in bonds they go from this world to the next.
sn22.117:1.4.comm: Accept variant jāyati (“is born”), which is supported by the parallel at SA 74 (以縛生.

sn22.117:1.5.pli: Vedanaṃ attato samanupassati …pe… vedanāya vā attānaṃ.

sn22.117:1.6.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano vedanābandhanabaddho santarabāhirabandhanabaddho atīradassī apāradassī, baddho jīyati baddho mīyati baddho asmā lokā paraṃ lokaṃ gacchati.

sn22.117:1.10.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano viññāṇabandhanabaddho santarabāhirabandhanabaddho atīradassī apāradassī, baddho jīyati baddho mīyati baddho asmā lokā paraṃ lokaṃ gacchati.
sn22.117:1.10.eng: They’re called an unlearned ordinary person who is bound to consciousness, inside and out. They see neither the near shore nor the far shore. They’re born in bonds and die in bonds, and in bonds they go from this world to the next.

sn22.117:2.1.pli: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī …pe… sappurisadhamme suvinīto
sn22.117:2.1.eng: A learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.117:2.2.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; na attani vā rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.117:2.2.eng: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.117:2.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako na rūpabandhanabaddho, na santarabāhirabandhanabaddho, tīradassī, pāradassī; ‘parimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn22.117:2.3.eng: They’re called a learned noble disciple who is not bound to form, inside or out. They see the near shore and the far shore. They’re free from suffering, I say.

sn22.117:2.8.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako na viññāṇabandhanabaddho, na santarabāhirabandhanabaddho, tīradassī, pāradassī, ‘parimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmī”ti.
sn22.117:2.8.eng: They’re called a learned noble disciple who is not bound to consciousness, inside or out. They see the near shore and the far shore. They’re free from suffering, I say.”

sn22.118:1.3.pli: rūpaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassathā”ti?
sn22.118:1.3.eng: Do you regard form like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.118:1.6.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.118:1.6.eng: Form should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.118:1.10.pli: viññāṇaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassathā”ti?
sn22.118:1.10.eng: consciousness like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.118:1.13.pli: Viññāṇaṃ, bhikkhave, ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ …pe…
sn22.118:1.13.eng: Consciousness should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.118:1.15.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.119:1.3.pli: rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassathā”ti?
sn22.119:1.3.eng: Do you regard form like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”

sn22.119:1.6.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.119:1.6.eng: Form should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.119:1.10.pli: viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassathā”ti?
sn22.119:1.10.eng: consciousness like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”

sn22.119:1.13.pli: Viññāṇaṃ, bhikkhave, ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ …
sn22.119:1.13.eng: Consciousness should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.119:1.15.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.12:1.4.pli: “rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, vedanā aniccā, saññā aniccā, saṅkhārā aniccā, viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ.
sn22.12:1.4.eng: “Mendicants, form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.

sn22.12:1.5.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
sn22.12:1.5.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.12:1.6.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.12:1.6.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn22.12:1.7.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn22.12:1.7.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.120:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that tighten the fetters, and the fetter.

sn22.120:1.4.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyā dhammā, katamaṃ saṃyojanaṃ?
sn22.120:1.4.eng: What are the things that tighten the fetters? And what is the fetter?

sn22.120:1.5.eng: Form is something that tightens the fetters.

sn22.120:1.6.pli: yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn22.120:1.6.eng: The desire and greed for it is the fetter.

sn22.120:1.10.eng: Consciousness is something that tightens the fetters.

sn22.120:1.11.pli: yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn22.120:1.11.eng: The desire and greed for it is the fetter.

sn22.120:1.12.pli: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, saṃyojaniyā dhammā, idaṃ saṃyojanan”ti.
sn22.120:1.12.eng: These are called the things that tighten the fetters, and this is the fetter.”

sn22.121:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that fuel grasping, and the grasping.

sn22.121:1.4.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, upādāniyā dhammā, katamaṃ upādānaṃ?
sn22.121:1.4.eng: What are the things that fuel grasping? And what is the grasping?

sn22.121:1.5.eng: Form is something that fuels grasping.

sn22.121:1.6.pli: yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha upādānaṃ.
sn22.121:1.6.eng: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.

sn22.121:1.10.eng: Consciousness is something that fuels grasping.

sn22.121:1.11.pli: yo tattha chandarāgo, taṃ tattha upādānaṃ.
sn22.121:1.11.eng: The desire and greed for it is the grasping.

sn22.121:1.12.pli: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, upādāniyā dhammā, idaṃ upādānan”ti.
sn22.121:1.12.eng: These are called the things that fuel grasping, and this is the grasping.”

sn22.122:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahākoṭṭhiko bārāṇasiyaṃ viharanti isipatane migadāye.
sn22.122:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
sn22.122:1.1.comm: Mahākoṭṭhita was one of the great disciples, and many of his conversations with Sāriputta are recorded. He was said to be foremost in the methods of textual analysis (AN 1.218:1.1), exemplified by such discussions as MN 43. His verse is at Thag 1.2:0.4.

sn22.122:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami …pe… etadavoca:
sn22.122:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, and said:

sn22.122:1.3.pli: “sīlavatāvuso, sāriputta, bhikkhunā katame dhammā yoniso manasikātabbā”ti?
sn22.122:1.3.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, what things should an ethical mendicant rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.122:1.4.pli: “Sīlavatāvuso, koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.122:1.4.eng: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, an ethical mendicant should rationally apply the mind to the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as gloom, as an affliction, as alien, as breaking apart, as empty, as not-self.

sn22.122:1.6.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.122:1.7.pli: Sīlavatāvuso, koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā ime pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.122:1.7.eng: An ethical mendicant should rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as gloom, as an affliction, as alien, as breaking apart, as empty, as not-self.

sn22.122:1.8.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati yaṃ sīlavā bhikkhu ime pañcupādānakkhandhe aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi karonto sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikareyyā”ti.
sn22.122:1.8.eng: It’s possible that an ethical mendicant who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of stream-entry.”

sn22.122:2.1.pli: “Sotāpannena panāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā katame dhammā yoniso manasi kātabbā”ti?
sn22.122:2.1.eng: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant stream-enterer rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.122:2.2.pli: “Sotāpannenapi kho, āvuso koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā ime pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.122:2.2.eng: “A mendicant stream-enterer should also rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.

sn22.122:2.3.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati yaṃ sotāpanno bhikkhu ime pañcupādānakkhandhe aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi karonto sakadāgāmiphalaṃ sacchikareyyā”ti.
sn22.122:2.3.eng: It’s possible that a mendicant stream-enterer who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of once-return.”

sn22.122:3.1.pli: “Sakadāgāminā panāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā katame dhammā yoniso manasi kātabbā”ti?
sn22.122:3.1.eng: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant once-returner rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.122:3.2.pli: “Sakadāgāmināpi kho, āvuso koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā ime pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.122:3.2.eng: “A mendicant once-returner should also rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.

sn22.122:3.3.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati yaṃ sakadāgāmī bhikkhu ime pañcupādānakkhandhe aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi karonto anāgāmiphalaṃ sacchikareyyā”ti.
sn22.122:3.3.eng: It’s possible that a mendicant once-returner who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of non-return.”

sn22.122:4.1.pli: “Anāgāminā panāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā katame dhammā yoniso manasi kātabbā”ti?
sn22.122:4.1.eng: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant non-returner rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.122:4.2.pli: “Anāgāmināpi kho, āvuso koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā ime pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.122:4.2.eng: “A mendicant non-returner should also rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.

sn22.122:4.3.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati yaṃ anāgāmī bhikkhu ime pañcupādānakkhandhe aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi karonto arahattaṃ sacchikareyyā”ti.
sn22.122:4.3.eng: It’s possible that a mendicant non-returner who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize perfection.”

sn22.122:5.1.pli: “Arahatā panāvuso sāriputta, katame dhammā yoniso manasi kātabbā”ti?
sn22.122:5.1.eng: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a perfected one rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.122:5.2.pli: “Arahatāpi kho, āvuso koṭṭhika, ime pañcupādānakkhandhe aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.122:5.2.eng: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, a perfected one should also rationally apply the mind to the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as gloom, as an affliction, as alien, as breaking apart, as empty, as not-self.

sn22.122:5.3.pli: Natthi, khvāvuso, arahato uttari karaṇīyaṃ katassa vā paticayo;
sn22.122:5.3.eng: A perfected one has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.

sn22.122:5.4.pli: api ca ime dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya ceva saṃvattanti satisampajaññāya cā”ti.
sn22.122:5.4.eng: Still, these things, when developed and cultivated, lead to blissful meditation in this life, and also to mindfulness and situational awareness.”

sn22.123:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahākoṭṭhiko bārāṇasiyaṃ viharanti isipatane migadāye.
sn22.123:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

sn22.123:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe… etadavoca:
sn22.123:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:

sn22.123:2.1.pli: “Sutavatāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā katame dhammā yoniso manasi kātabbā”ti?
sn22.123:2.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a learned mendicant rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.123:2.2.pli: “Sutavatāvuso koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.123:2.2.eng: “A learned mendicant should rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.

sn22.123:2.4.eng: That is, the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.123:2.5.pli: Sutavatāvuso koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā ime pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.123:2.5.eng: A learned mendicant should rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.

sn22.123:2.6.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati—yaṃ sutavā bhikkhu ime pañcupādānakkhandhe aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi karonto sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikareyyā”ti.
sn22.123:2.6.eng: It’s possible that a learned mendicant who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of stream-entry.”

sn22.123:3.1.pli: “Sotāpannena panāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā katame dhammā yoniso manasi kātabbā”ti?
sn22.123:3.1.eng: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a mendicant stream-enterer rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.123:3.2.pli: “Sotāpannenapi kho āvuso koṭṭhika, bhikkhunā ime pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.123:3.2.eng: “A mendicant stream-enterer should also rationally apply the mind to these five grasping aggregates as impermanent … as not-self.

sn22.123:3.3.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, āvuso, vijjati—yaṃ sotāpanno bhikkhu ime pañcupādānakkhandhe aniccato …pe… anattato yoniso manasi karonto sakadāgāmiphalaṃ …pe…
sn22.123:3.3.eng: It’s possible that a mendicant stream-enterer who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of once-return.” …

sn22.123:3.4.eng: “It’s possible that a mendicant once-returner who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of non-return.” …

sn22.123:3.5.eng: “It’s possible that a mendicant non-returner who rationally applies the mind to the five grasping aggregates will realize the fruit of perfection.”

sn22.123:4.1.pli: “Arahatā panāvuso sāriputta, katame dhammā yoniso manasi kātabbā”ti?
sn22.123:4.1.eng: “But Reverend Sāriputta, what things should a perfected one rationally apply the mind to?”

sn22.123:4.2.pli: “Arahatāpi khvāvuso koṭṭhika, ime pañcupādānakkhandhā aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato yoniso manasi kātabbā.
sn22.123:4.2.eng: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, a perfected one should rationally apply the mind to the five grasping aggregates as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as gloom, as an affliction, as alien, as breaking apart, as empty, as not-self.

sn22.123:4.3.pli: Natthi, khvāvuso, arahato uttari karaṇīyaṃ, katassa vā paticayo;
sn22.123:4.3.eng: A perfected one has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.

sn22.123:4.4.pli: api ca kho ime dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya ceva saṃvattanti satisampajaññāya cā”ti.
sn22.123:4.4.eng: Still, these things, when developed and cultivated, lead to blissful meditation in this life, and also to mindfulness and situational awareness.”

sn22.124:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā kappo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā kappo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.124:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Kappa went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn22.124:1.2.comm: Appearing in this discourse and the next, this may be the same Kappa whose verses are at Thag 10.5.

sn22.124:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?
sn22.124:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs?”

sn22.124:2.1.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, kappa, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn22.124:2.1.eng: “Kappa, one truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.124:2.2.eng: One truly sees any kind of feeling …

sn22.124:2.5.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn22.124:2.5.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.124:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, kappa, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti.
sn22.124:2.6.eng: That’s how to know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs.”

sn22.125:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā kappo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.125:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, Venerable Kappa said to the Buddha:

sn22.125:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhā samatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti?
sn22.125:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed?”

sn22.125:2.1.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, kappa, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ …pe… sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādāvimutto hoti.
sn22.125:2.1.eng: “Kappa, one is freed by not grasping having truly seen any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.125:2.2.eng: One is freed by not grasping having truly seen any kind of feeling …

sn22.125:2.5.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādāvimutto hoti.
sn22.125:2.5.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.125:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, kappa, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhā samatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti.
sn22.125:2.6.eng: That’s how to know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed.”
